column7: Loose bunch in produce bag + plastic twist-tie
column8: Lowest-cost option that satisfies health policy; kale #3 on EWG Dirty Dozen so organic REQUIRED by rule (not optional)
column10: Pros: LOWEST COST organic leafy green ($1.99/lb), kale #3 Dirty Dozen (organic mandatory), high nutrient density (vitamin K 684% DV, vitamin A 206% DV, vitamin C 134% DV per cup cooked), versatile (sauté/salad/soup/smoothie), hearty texture (holds up to cooking), 5-7 day shelf life refrigerated, year-round availability. Cons: Requires washing and prep (remove stems, chop leaves = 5-10 min), 1-lb bunch may increase waste for small households (vs baby kale clamshells), conventional sourcing location not disclosed (generic store brand), stems fibrous (requires remove before eating), bitter flavor vs chard (some prefer milder greens). Premium over this tier: BALANCED +$1.50/lb (+75%), CONSCIOUS +$10.81/lb (+543%). RECALL STATUS: ✅ ZERO kale recalls found (FDA database searched Jan 2026).
column12: FreshDirect price listing + EWG Dirty Dozen 2025 (#3 kale/collard/mustard greens = organic mandatory)

column7: Loose bunch in produce bag + plastic twist-tie
column8: Moderate cost increase for dietary variety while maintaining organic consistency. Chard NOT on EWG Dirty Dozen or Clean Fifteen (middle category) = organic optional, chosen for consistency with CHEAPER tier organic greens. FLAVOR DIFFERENCE vs kale: Milder, earthy, slightly sweet (vs kale = bitter, peppery). COOKING DIFFERENCE: Two textures in one (stems cook longer 5-7 min, leaves cook quickly 2-3 min). NUTRITION: Similar to kale but with more magnesium and iron. 75% premium over CHEAPER justified by: dietary variety, milder flavor, dual-texture cooking. RECALL SAFE: ZERO chard recalls found (FDA database searched Jan 2026).
column10: Pros: DIETARY VARIETY (different flavor than kale - milder, earthy, slightly sweet vs bitter), TWO TEXTURES in one (stems sauté separately 5-7 min, leaves wilt quickly 2-3 min), versatile (sauté, braise, soup, frittata, pasta), organic consistency with CHEAPER tier, high magnesium (38% DV per cup) and iron (22% DV), colorful stems (white, red, rainbow varieties = visual appeal), milder than kale (), year-round availability. Cons: 75% more expensive than CHEAPER kale ($3.49 vs $1.99/lb = $1.50/lb premium), chard middle category (organic optional, not required like kale Dirty Dozen), shorter shelf life than kale (3-5 days vs 5-7 days, more delicate leaves), requires prep (wash thoroughly, separate stems from leaves = 5-10 min), stems requires cook separately (more technique than simple kale sauté), generic sourcing (no farm transparency). Premium over CHEAPER: +$1.50/lb (+75%). Savings vs CONSCIOUS: -$9.31/lb (-73%). RECALL STATUS: ✅ ZERO chard recalls found (FDA database searched Jan 2026).
column12: FreshDirect price listing + EWG 2025 (chard not on Dirty Dozen or Clean Fifteen = middle category)

column7: Plastic clamshell (5oz, thicker plastic per oz)
column8: Meets conscious criteria: organic required for kale (Dirty Dozen #3), verifiable regional cooperative sourcing, smaller pack size reduces spoilage risk
column9: USDA Organic, Lancaster Farm Fresh Cooperative
column10: Pros: LANCASTER FARM FRESH cooperative (120+ member farms, farmer-owned cooperative, democratic governance), REGIONAL (Lancaster County PA ~75 miles = ), YOUNG TENDER KALE (baby leaves, less fibrous than mature, can eat raw without massaging), organic certified (kale Dirty Dozen #3 = mandatory), smaller 5oz pack (reduces waste for 1-2 households, use within 2-3 days), on sale pricing ($12.80/lb, regular likely $15-18/lb), clamshell packaging (stays fresher than bunched, though plastic), farmer accountability (120+ known farms vs generic commodity). Cons: MOST EXPENSIVE ($12.80/lb = 543% more than CHEAPER, $10.81/lb premium), plastic clamshell packaging (not eco-friendly despite freshness benefits), very small portion (5oz = 1-2 servings only, may need multiple for larger households), sale price (regular price unknown but likely $15-18/lb = even more expensive), young kale premium (tender = less yield per plant = higher cost), winter growing method not disclosed (greenhouse vs hoop house = transparency gap), exact farm-of-origin not specified (one of 120+ farms in cooperative). Premium over CHEAPER: +$10.81/lb (+543%). Premium over BALANCED: +$9.31/lb (+267%). RECALL STATUS: ✅ Lancaster Farm Fresh Cooperative ZERO recalls found (FDA database searched Jan 2026).

column8: Lowest-cost option; onions #4 on EWG Clean Fifteen (low pesticide concern), so organic not required by health policy
column10: Pros: BEST VALUE ($0.99/lb baseline), EWG Clean Fifteen #4 (papery skin removed before eating = natural pesticide barrier, conventional acceptable), LONGEST STORAGE LIFE (1-2 months counter, 2-3 months refrigerated = storage crop), most versatile (soups/stews/roasted/caramelized/sautéed), high yield (~90% edible after removing outer papery layers), year-round availability (storage crop + imports), widely available (bulk = weigh exact amount needed), quercetin antioxidants. Cons: Conventional farming (synthetic pesticides/fertilizers on fields, though Clean Fifteen = low residues), generic sourcing (no farm transparency), strongest pungent flavor (high sulfur content = makes you cry when cutting, not suitable raw), bulk packaging (requires weigh/bag yourself, less convenient than pre-bagged), some prefer milder sweet onion flavor. Premium over this tier: BALANCED +$0.50/lb (+51%), CONSCIOUS +$1.00/lb (+101%). RECALL STATUS: ✅ ZERO onion recalls found (FDA database searched Jan 2026).
column12: FreshDirect price list + EWG Clean Fifteen 2025 (#4 onions = conventional acceptable, thick skin removed before eating)

column8: Moderate price increase for FLAVOR and versatility while remaining compliant with health policy. Sweet onions Clean Fifteen #4 (organic optional). FLAVOR DIFFERENCE vs yellow: Milder, sweeter (lower sulfur content = less pungent, less crying when cutting). COOKING DIFFERENCE: Better raw applications (salads, sandwiches, burgers, salsas, relish) + still suitable cooked (caramelized, roasted, grilled). SWEETNESS: Natural sugars higher than yellow onions = caramelizes faster, sweeter flavor. 51% premium over CHEAPER justified by: milder flavor, raw versatility, less crying when cutting. RECALL SAFE: ZERO onion recalls found (FDA database searched Jan 2026).
column10: Pros: MILDER SWEETER FLAVOR (lower sulfur content = less pungent, less crying when cutting), BETTER RAW APPLICATIONS (salads, sandwiches, burgers, salsas, relish vs yellow = primarily cooked), still versatile cooked (caramelizes faster due to higher natural sugars, roasted, grilled), Clean Fifteen #4 (conventional acceptable), 51% premium over CHEAPER justified by flavor upgrade, year-round availability, widely available bulk. Cons: 51% more expensive than CHEAPER ($1.49 vs $0.99/lb = $0.50/lb premium), SHORTER STORAGE LIFE (3-4 weeks vs 1-2 months yellow onions, higher water content = spoils faster), conventional (no organic certification, though Clean Fifteen = low pesticide concern), generic sourcing (no farm transparency), still bulk packaging (weigh/bag yourself), higher water content (can get soggy when cooked if not careful). Premium over CHEAPER: +$0.50/lb (+51%). Savings vs CONSCIOUS: -$0.50/lb (-25%). RECALL STATUS: ✅ ZERO onion recalls found (FDA database searched Jan 2026).

Berries = hand-picked, eaten raw, delicate skin.

ENVIRONMENTAL: Organic farming (organic farming practices, no synthetic pesticides/fertilizers). SAFETY: Driscoll's brand traceability (barcode to field/harvest date, FDA GAPs, third-party audits). NOT linked to Hepatitis A: FDA/Senasica confirmed Driscoll's NOT involved in 2022-2023 outbreak. 41% premium over CHEAPER generic organic ($9.99 vs $6.99) justified by: (1) Strawberries #1 Dirty Dozen (organic essential), (2) Brand traceability + food safety program, (3) Environmental benefits. 16oz appropriate: same portion as CHEAPER.

Cons: 41% more expensive than CHEAPER generic organic ($3.00 premium), still imported even if organic (Mexico, CA = 1,000-3,000 miles), plastic clamshell packaging, 3-5 day shelf life (requires use quickly), organic does NOT eliminate food safety risk (still hand-picked, eaten raw, delicate skin), berries = highest-risk produce, wash thoroughly before eating, Driscoll's past recalls (2022 pesticide conventional, 2021 Canada metal - both resolved). Premium over CHEAPER: +$3.00 (+43%). Premium over BALANCED: +$3.00 (+43%) BUT larger portion (16oz vs 6oz). RECALL STATUS: ✅ NO active recalls. Driscoll's organic strawberries: ZERO recalls found.

column8: HEALTH PRIORITY: Bell peppers #9 on EWG Dirty Dozen. Organic certification REQUIRED per health-first rule. UNCOMMON PRICING: Organic green pepper $2.99/lb = SAME PRICE as conventional green ($2.99/lb). Zero cost trade-off to eliminate pesticide exposure (typically organic costs 30-100% more, this is 0% premium). User gets organic certification for FREE. Versatile: cooked/raw applications. High yield: ~82% edible after removing stem/seeds. Vitamin C rich: 127% DV per cup. RECALL SAFE: Wiers Farm organic bell peppers (July 2024) = Walmart brand ONLY, not FreshDirect generic organic.
column10: Pros: ORGANIC AT CONVENTIONAL PRICE ($2.99/lb = 0% premium, uncommon), bell peppers #9 Dirty Dozen = organic REQUIRED not optional, eliminates pesticide exposure at zero cost penalty, high vitamin C (127% DV per cup), versatile (cooked/raw), high yield (82% edible), year-round availability (organic greenhouse), stores well (7-10 days), NOT in recalls (Wiers Farm organic = Walmart ONLY, FreshDirect = different supplier), CHEAPER than conventional red ($2.99 vs $3.49/lb), CHEAPER than organic red ($2.99 vs $5.49/lb = 45% savings). Cons: Still less sweet than red/yellow/orange (harvested early like conventional green), organic green NOT nutritionally superior to conventional red (red has 3X vitamin A), greenhouse-grown even if organic (~500-1,000 miles), bulk packaging (weigh/bag yourself), mild flavor (less sweet than colored peppers), generic brand (no farm transparency beyond USDA Organic cert). Premium over conventional: +$0 (SAME PRICE, 0% premium!). RECALL STATUS: ✅ SAFE. Wiers Farm organic = Walmart UPC 073064201416 ONLY, not FreshDirect bulk organic.

column8: SWEET + NUTRITIOUS + AFFORDABLE. Red bell peppers = fully ripe green peppers (sweeter, higher nutrition). Red peppers #9 Dirty Dozen (same as green) BUT conventional acceptable at BALANCED tier (organic mandatory only at CHEAPER tier per rule). $3.49/lb: Only 17% more than organic green ($2.99/lb), significant sweetness upgrade. Nutrition boost: Red peppers 3X vitamin A of green (93% DV vs 11% DV), same vitamin C (127% DV). Sweetest flavor: fully ripe = better raw (salads, hummus, crudités). Versatile: also suitable cooked. Still affordable: $3.49/lb vs organic red $5.49/lb (37% savings). RECALL SAFE: Wiers Farm = Walmart/Aldi ONLY, not FreshDirect.
column10: Pros: SWEETEST bell pepper (fully ripe, natural sugars), 3X vitamin A of green (93% DV vs 11% DV per cup), same vitamin C as green (127% DV), better raw (salads, hummus, snacking), also suitable cooked (roasted, grilled), only 17% more than organic green ($0.50/lb premium = high value for sweetness + nutrition boost), year-round availability (greenhouse), stores well (7-10 days), NOT in recalls (Wiers Farm = Walmart/Aldi ONLY, FreshDirect = different supplier). Cons: Peppers #9 Dirty Dozen but conventional acceptable at BALANCED tier (CHEAPER tier requires organic), 17% more expensive than organic green ($3.49 vs $2.99/lb), still conventional (synthetic pesticides/fertilizers permitted), greenhouse-grown (not field-grown, ~500-1,000 miles), 57% cheaper than organic red BUT no organic certification, bulk packaging (weigh/bag yourself). Premium over CHEAPER: +$0.50/lb (+17%). Savings vs CONSCIOUS: -$2.00/lb (-36%). RECALL STATUS: ✅ SAFE. Wiers Farm = Walmart/Aldi brands ONLY (not FreshDirect).

column8: HEALTH + ENVIRONMENTAL PRIORITY. HEALTH: Organic certified (bell peppers #9 Dirty Dozen = organic reduces pesticide exposure). Red = fully ripe (sweetest, 3X vitamin A of green 93% DV, vitamin C 127% DV). ENVIRONMENTAL: Organic farming (organic farming practices, no synthetic pesticides/fertilizers). 83% premium over CHEAPER organic green ($5.49 vs $2.99/lb) justified by: (1) Red color = sweetness + nutrition boost (3X vitamin A), (2) Organic certification (Dirty Dozen #9), (3) Environmental benefits. RECALL SAFE: Wiers Farm organic = Walmart ONLY, not FreshDirect.

Premium over CHEAPER: +$2.50/lb (+83%). Premium over BALANCED: +$2.00/lb (+57%). RECALL STATUS: ✅ SAFE. Wiers Farm organic = Walmart ONLY.

column7: Loose bulk (sold by pound, minimum 2 pieces)
column8: LOWEST $/LB SUMMER SQUASH. Green zucchini = most versatile summer squash (raw/cooked, savory/sweet). $1.99/lb: cheapest fresh whole squash/zucchini. High yield: ~94% edible (soft skin eaten). Summer squash middle category (not Dirty Dozen, not Clean Fifteen). Conventional acceptable WITH CAUTION: soft edible skin (moderate pesticide exposure, not peeled). Wash thoroughly before use. Fast cooking: 5-10 minutes. RECALL SAFE: Pero (Nov 2024) = SLICED product FL/MO/IL/VA (not NJ, not whole fresh), Wiers Farm (July 2024) = Walmart brand ONLY.
column10: Pros: CHEAPEST whole squash ($1.99/lb baseline), versatile (raw/cooked, spiralize at home, grill/sauté/bake/bread), high yield (94% edible, soft skin eaten), fast cooking (5-10 min sauté vs 45-60 min roasting winter squash), low-calorie (21 cal/cup, 95% water), vitamin C (35% DV per cup), NOT in recalls (Pero = sliced FL/MO/IL/VA, Wiers = Walmart ONLY), stores well (7-10 days), year-round availability, no peeling needed. Cons: Conventional (synthetic pesticides/fertilizers permitted), requires buy minimum 2 pieces (typically 1-1.5lb total = $2-3 minimum), mild flavor (some prefer sweeter winter squash), summer squash spoils faster than winter squash (7-10 days vs 1-3 months), generic brand (no farm transparency). CAUTION: Zucchini not on Dirty Dozen but SOFT EDIBLE SKIN (not thick skin) increases pesticide exposure; wash thoroughly before eating. Organic available at $2.99/lb for those concerned. Premium over this tier: BALANCED +$0.50/lb (+25%), CONSCIOUS +$1.00/lb (+50%). RECALL STATUS: ✅ SAFE. Pero = sliced product FL/MO/IL/VA (NOT NJ, NOT whole fresh), Wiers = Walmart brand ONLY.
column12: FDA Recall Database (Pero sliced Nov 2024 FL/MO/IL/VA, Wiers organic July 2024 Walmart ONLY), FreshDirect supplier verification (different from Wiers Farm, sells whole not sliced), USDA FoodData Central (zucchini: 21 cal/cup, vitamin C 35% DV, 95% water), yield calculation (94% edible, soft skin eaten), EWG 2025 (summer squash middle category, NOT on Dirty Dozen or Clean Fifteen)

column7: Loose bulk (sold by pound, whole squash)
column8: WINTER SQUASH + LOCAL + ORGANIC. Butternut squash = most popular winter squash (sweet, versatile, nutrient-dense). Lancaster Farm Fresh: 120+ member cooperative (Lancaster County PA ~150 miles), branded packaging, farm traceability. Local: Pennsylvania ~150 miles from NJ (vs imported summer squash). Organic: USDA certified (no synthetic pesticides/fertilizers). Butternut middle category (not Dirty Dozen, not Clean Fifteen) = organic optional, chosen for cooperative benefits. Nutrition: Vitamin A 457% DV per cup (9X more than zucchini). Long storage: 1-3 months counter/pantry. RECALL SAFE: Lancaster zero recalls, different supplier from Pero/Wiers.
column9: USDA Organic, Lancaster Farm Fresh Cooperative (120+ member farms, Lancaster County PA)
column10: Pros: LANCASTER FARM FRESH branded (cooperative traceability, 120+ member farms), organic certified (reduces pesticide exposure for middle category vegetable), LOCAL (PA ~150 miles = shortest supply chain in squash category), winter squash nutrition (vitamin A 457% DV, fiber 3g per cup, 9X vitamin A vs zucchini), long storage (1-3 months counter/pantry vs 7-10 days summer squash), versatile (roasted, soup, puree, baked goods), sweet flavor (natural sugars, kid-friendly), NOT in recalls (Lancaster zero recalls, Pero/Wiers = different suppliers), cooperative structure (farm accountability, supports small PA farms). Cons: 67% more expensive than conventional butternut ($2.49 vs $1.49/lb), still 25% more than CHEAPER summer squash ($2.49 vs $1.99/lb), requires prep (peeling, seeding, cubing = 15-20 minutes), hard skin (need sharp knife), long cooking time (45-60 min roasting vs 5-10 min summer squash), lower yield than zucchini (~70% edible after peeling/seeding vs 94%), heavier squash (2-4lbs typical = $5-10 per squash), butternut middle category (organic optional, not Dirty Dozen). Premium over CHEAPER: +$0.50/lb (+25%). Savings vs CONSCIOUS: -$0.50/lb (-17%). RECALL STATUS: ✅ SAFE. Lancaster: ZERO recalls, Pero/Wiers = different suppliers.

column8: ORGANIC + UNIQUE NUTRITION + VERSATILE. Spaghetti squash = unique winter squash (stringy flesh = low-carb pasta substitute). Organic certified: reduces pesticide exposure. Spaghetti squash middle category (not Dirty Dozen, not Clean Fifteen) = organic optional, chosen for health-conscious dietary flexibility. $2.99/lb: Only 50% premium over conventional spaghetti ($1.99/lb), 20% premium over Lancaster butternut ($2.49/lb). Nutrition: Low-calorie (42 cal/cup vs 200+ cal pasta), vitamin C, beta-carotene, fiber. Dietary flexibility: Gluten-free, keto-friendly, paleo, vegan pasta alternative. Long storage: 1-3 months counter/pantry. RECALL SAFE: whole fresh organic (different from Pero sliced/Wiers packaged).
column10: Pros: ORGANIC certified (reduces pesticide exposure for middle category vegetable), unique nutrition (stringy flesh = pasta substitute, 42 cal/cup vs 200+ cal pasta), dietary flexibility (gluten-free, keto, paleo, vegan, low-carb), versatile (use in ANY pasta recipe - marinara, alfredo, carbonara, stir-fry, casseroles, salads), only 50% premium over conventional spaghetti ($2.99 vs $1.99/lb = reasonable), long storage (1-3 months whole uncut), vitamin C (9% DV per cup), beta-carotene, fiber, NOT in recalls (whole fresh vs Pero sliced/Wiers packaged), easy prep (bake whole, scrape strands with fork = less cutting than butternut). Premium over CHEAPER: +$1.00/lb (+50%). Premium over BALANCED: +$0.50/lb (+20%). RECALL STATUS: ✅ SAFE. Whole fresh organic (different from Pero sliced, Wiers Walmart packaged).

column8: HEALTH PRIORITY: Green beans #12 on EWG Dirty Dozen. Organic certification MANDATORY per health-first rule, not optional. Beans eaten whole with skin (high pesticide exposure if conventional). 201% more expensive than conventional snipped ($7.99 vs $2.65/lb) BUT health rule prioritizes pesticide elimination for Dirty Dozen items. Lost convenience (no microwavable bag, requires trim ends manually) to gain organic certification. 12oz appropriate: 3-4 servings, small household portion. Versatile: side dish, stir-fry, salads, casseroles. RECALL SAFE: Wiers Farm (July 2024) = Walmart/Aldi standard green beans ONLY, NOT FreshDirect organic. Target (March 2025) = CANNED (not fresh).
column10: Pros: ORGANIC certified (green beans #12 Dirty Dozen = conventional has high pesticide residues, organic MANDATORY not optional), eliminates Dirty Dozen pesticide exposure for vegetable eaten whole with skin, appropriate portion (12oz = 3-4 servings, small households), versatile (side dish, stir-fry, salads), vitamin K (20% DV), vitamin C (20% DV), fiber (4g per cup), NOT in recalls (Wiers Farm = Walmart/Aldi standard beans ONLY, Target = canned not fresh), year-round availability. Cons: 201% more expensive than conventional snipped ($5.34/lb premium = significant cost increase), lost convenience (no microwavable bag, requires trim ends manually = 5-10 min prep), lost snipped benefit (requires do prep yourself), on sale conventional was $2.65/lb (regular $3.98/lb), 12oz = smaller package than 1lb (may need multiple for larger households), generic brand (no farm transparency beyond USDA Organic), green beans #12 Dirty Dozen (organic required regardless of cost). HEALTH TRADE-OFF: Lost convenience (microwavable bag, snipped ends) and 201% cost increase to gain organic certification. Health rule prioritizes pesticide elimination over convenience/cost for Dirty Dozen items. Premium over conventional snipped: +$5.34/lb (+201%). RECALL STATUS: ✅ SAFE. Wiers Farm = Walmart/Aldi standard beans ONLY (UPC 073064200846), NOT FreshDirect organic. Target = CANNED (UPC 0 85239-11628 9), NOT fresh.

column8: UNIQUE NUTRITION + EAT-WHOLE POD. Snap peas = sweetest legume vegetable (6-8g sugar per cup vs 5g green beans). Eat entire pod: crispy edible pod + tender peas inside (no shelling). Snap peas NOT on 2025 Dirty Dozen (different from green beans #12), middle category. Conventional acceptable at BALANCED tier (CHEAPER tier requires organic for Dirty Dozen items). $9.32/lb: 17% more than CHEAPER organic green beans BUT different vegetable (crunchier texture, sweeter flavor, eaten raw or cooked). Versatile: raw (salads, crudités, snacking), cooked (stir-fry, steamed). Nutrition: Vitamin C (98% DV per cup = 5X green beans). RECALL SAFE: ZERO snap pea recalls.
column10: Pros: UNIQUE VEGETABLE (sweetest legume, 6-8g sugar per cup), eat entire pod (crispy shell + tender peas, no shelling), vitamin C (98% DV per cup = 5X green beans!), versatile (raw snacking/salads/crudités OR cooked stir-fry/steamed), crunchy texture (different from soft green beans), appropriate portion (12oz = 2-3 servings, use within 3-5 days), NOT in recalls (ZERO snap pea recalls found), can eat raw (vitamin C preserved). Cons: Snap peas middle category (not Dirty Dozen) so conventional acceptable at BALANCED tier, 17% more expensive than CHEAPER organic green beans ($9.32 vs $7.99/lb = $1.33/lb premium), different vegetable category (not directly comparable to green beans), shorter shelf life (3-5 days vs 7-10 days green beans), conventional (synthetic pesticides, peas middle category but edible pod = exposure), requires use quickly (spoils faster than hearty green beans), 12oz = small package (may need multiple for larger households), generic brand (no farm transparency), can be stringy (some pods have tough strings along seam). Premium over CHEAPER: +$1.33/lb (+17%). Savings vs CONSCIOUS: -$3.33/lb (-36%) BUT different vegetables. RECALL STATUS: ✅ SAFE. ZERO snap pea recalls. Wiers Farm/Target = green beans ONLY, Deep brand (2025) = FROZEN SPROUTED beans (not snap peas).

column8: ORGANIC + GOURMET VARIETY. French beans (haricots verts) = thin tender gourmet variety (vs thick American green beans). Organic certified: reduces pesticide exposure. French beans = same category as green beans (both eaten whole with skin). Green beans #12 Dirty Dozen so French beans likely similar pesticide concern = organic beneficial. $5.99/lb: 25% CHEAPER than CHEAPER tier organic standard green beans ($5.99 vs $7.99/lb) due to larger pack (~1lb vs 12oz economy). Gourmet quality: thinner (pencil-width), more tender, delicate flavor. Versatile: classic French preparations (haricots verts almondine), roasted, blanched, salads. RECALL SAFE: Wiers Farm = standard green beans Walmart/Aldi ONLY, NOT FreshDirect French beans organic.

Cons: Still requires trimming (ends requires be snipped, 5-10 min prep), ""approximately 1lb"" (variable weight, cannot choose exact amount), French beans = gourmet specialty (may not be familiar to all households, not as common as standard green beans), shorter shelf life than standard green beans (5-7 days vs 7-10 days), French beans likely similar Dirty Dozen concern as green beans #12 (both eaten whole with skin, organic beneficial). Savings vs CHEAPER: -$2.00/lb (-25%). Savings vs BALANCED: -$3.33/lb (-36%) BUT different vegetables. RECALL STATUS: ✅ SAFE.
